details.description:
During the first three projects in this advanced studio, we prensented our work as a group of three, produced a schematic design for a Museum of Climate Change that is to be located at Pier 57 (250 11th Avenue) in Manhattan. Our schematic design represented the main design intent, concept, and presented all of the major
spaces at the museum. The third project requires our team to further develop this schematic design, so
that all of the programmatic elements have been carefully considered and are present in the museum.
details.name: Climate Change Museum in NY

modules.text:
Project Description
 
During the first three projects in this advanced studio, we prensented our work as a group of three, produced a schematic design for a Museum of Climate Change that is to be located at Pier 57 (250 11th Avenue) in Manhattan. Our schematic design represented the main design intent, concept, and presented all of the major
spaces at the museum. The third project requires our team to further develop this schematic design, so
that all of the programmatic elements have been carefully considered and are present in the museum.
modules.text_plain: Project Description During the first three projects in this advanced studio, we prensented our work as a group of three, produced a schematic design for a Museum of Climate Change that is to be located at Pier 57 (250 11th Avenue) in Manhattan. Our schematic design represented the main design intent, concept, and presented all of the majorspaces at the museum. The third project requires our team to further develop this schematic design, sothat all of the programmatic elements have been carefully considered and are present in the museum.

modules.text:
Design Concept
 
By selectively picking some conclusions and ignoring others, it is possible for human beings to form one-sided judgments on the issue of climate change. Our climate change museum would provides more opportunities for people to think about climate change from various perspectives, giving people more a comprehensive understanding of climate change. This project aims to communicate the idea of climate change solely through the presentation of climate change facts, without passing judgement, leaving space for visitors to reflect on their own experiences within the museum.
 
We selected our exhibition program based on three categories, which are a loop from sea creatures, to land animals, to birds or insects that fly in the sky. Through immersive experiences throughout the museum, people would experience climate change not only as a human being but also from the perspective of other creatures.
 
Another exhibition area would be on top of these experience rooms, exhibiting “what is happening” and “ why it is happening” under the subject of climate change, which would give people more detailed information, corresponding to the immersive experience room underneath them.
 
Global warming is also one of the reasons for the increasing weather issues in urban areas. We selected places like Beijing, California and Moyale in Kenya, which reflect the current situation of our cities in a global perspective to bring people back to the grim reality of our living world.
 
A ribbon of interactive systems would run through the whole journey in the museum for people to exchange their observations. At the end of the journey, people would have a chance to express their own opinions after the experience with both good and bad effects of climate change on our living world in all aspects.
 
We try to immerse the museum within the site by creating visual connections between interior and exterior, as well as a coherent picture of our museum within the urban context.
modules.text_plain: Design Concept By selectively picking some conclusions and ignoring others, it is possible for human beings to form one-sided judgments on the issue of climate change. Our climate change museum would provides more opportunities for people to think about climate change from various perspectives, giving people more a comprehensive understanding of climate change. This project aims to communicate the idea of climate change solely through the presentation of climate change facts, without passing judgement, leaving space for visitors to reflect on their own experiences within the museum. We selected our exhibition program based on three categories, which are a loop from sea creatures, to land animals, to birds or insects that fly in the sky. Through immersive experiences throughout the museum, people would experience climate change not only as a human being but also from the perspective of other creatures. Another exhibition area would be on top of these experience rooms, exhibiting “what is happening” and “ why it is happening” under the subject of climate change, which would give people more detailed information, corresponding to the immersive experience room underneath them. Global warming is also one of the reasons for the increasing weather issues in urban areas. We selected places like Beijing, California and Moyale in Kenya, which reflect the current situation of our cities in a global perspective to bring people back to the grim reality of our living world. A ribbon of interactive systems would run through the whole journey in the museum for people to exchange their observations. At the end of the journey, people would have a chance to express their own opinions after the experience with both good and bad effects of climate change on our living world in all aspects. We try to immerse the museum within the site by creating visual connections between interior and exterior, as well as a coherent picture of our museum within the urban context.

details.description:
This page shows version 1. This project is ongoing.

my room is a collection of bedrooms from Tumblr and deviantArt searches conducted in 2013. The majority of the images come from deviantArt and are from within the last 6 years of posts. 

The content and composition of these images and their placement on the internet locate them in spaces between public and private, revealing both intimate personal information and carefully curated illusions of personality. By viewing them out of their original contexts in a collection, we can begin to understand this group of individuals who are, like the images themselves, unique and original yet strangely familiar.
details.name: my room

details.description: An exploration of the relationship of scale within interior architecture.
details.name: What is Interior Architecture?

modules.text: Interior Architecture is driven by the human body.  It caters / reacts / fits / controls / emphasizes / distorts / manipulates / predicts / holds / molds to / supports / guides / etc. how the body will move and feel in space. For this project I had to create a paper model for the human scale. If we look at the model at a one to one scale it functions as a protective garment - fitting the body while camouflaging the form. But if we imagine the model to be at 1/8” scale it suddenly becomes a cavernous space the body can freely wander through and explore.
modules.text_plain: Interior Architecture is driven by the human body.  It caters / reacts / fits / controls / emphasizes / distorts / manipulates / predicts / holds / molds to / supports / guides / etc. how the body will move and feel in space. For this project I had to create a paper model for the human scale. If we look at the model at a one to one scale it functions as a protective garment - fitting the body while camouflaging the form. But if we imagine the model to be at 1/8” scale it suddenly becomes a cavernous space the body can freely wander through and explore.

details.description:
19 Slip Knots is a two-channel video installation. Two twenty-one-inch video monitors are placed on pedestals and separated by about two and a half feet of space between the pedestals. The screens face each other (inward), and each screen has a line of maroon yarn emerging from the bottom. The two lines of yarn cascade down the front of the pedestals and fall into a large mound in the space between the two pedestals on the floor. Both screens are cropped and centrally focused on my mouth. One screen displays me pulling a continuous string of yarn out of my mouth, while the opposite screen shows me pushing a perpetual bundle of yarn into my mouth. Each screen broadcasts exaggerated sounds of the yarn entering and leaving my mouth. I recite short sentences between the two screens to present the illusion that the monitors are conversing with each other. 

Screen 1: They think it needs to be concealed.
Screen 2: They no longer have an influence over how we handle this.
Screen 1: Everyone will blame us.
Screen 2: It isn’t our fault.
Screen 1: To them it will be. 

The color and texture of the yarn after mixing with my saliva imitates an umbilical cord or blood-stained ectoplasm, creating a very visceral visual and auditory experience for the viewer. 

“Woman’s blood is thus linked to the possession of supernatural powers, powers which historically and mythologically have been associated with the representation of woman as witch.” -Barbara Creed, The Monstrous~Feminine, 79.

The concept of ingesting and regurgitating the internal alludes to the need for catharsis but demand for repression. I intended the installation to take on anthropomorphic qualities to reference the abject body: The monitors are positioned at the level of my mouth, while the pedestals used for the installation are tan, resembling the color of my skin. In A Manifesto for Cyborgs, Donna Haraway comments, “Communications technologies and biotechnologies are the crucial tools recrafting our bodies. These tools embody and enforce new social relations for women worldwide”  The introduction of communications technologies and biotechnologies as an instrument for “social relations for women worldwide” adds a layer of suppression to ideas of self. The feminine form is further removed from itself, and what is left is the abject.  

Speculative fiction writers, such as Johanna Russ and Margaret Atwood, introduce the possibilities of a world in which technological advancements reconstruct the female form. The Female Man by Johanna Russ and Oryx and Crake by Margaret Atwood are fantastical rebellions against reality rather than suggested replacements for it. By approaching topics regarding the dysfunction of a male-dominated society in a science fiction format, Johanna Russ and Margaret Atwood are not attempting to construct a manifesto for the future; rather, they are attempting to actualize their rage through tangibility. I believe the process of creating 19 Slip Knots was an attempt to make my trauma more tangible to better understand it. In Parable of the Sower, Octavia E. Bulter notes, “Sometimes naming a thing—giving it a name or discovering its name—helps one to begin to understand it. Knowing the name of a thing and knowing what that thing is for gives me even more of a handle on it.”  Rather than directly disclosing the source of my trauma, the work becomes the naming of the violent event that is the catalyst for my trauma.
details.name: 19 Slip Knots

details.description:
Sticks and Stones is a mixed-media performance in which I hold up my shirt to expose my stomach to a projection beam. The projector imprints sections of text in varying sizes of font and varying shades of skin tones onto and across my stomach. Projected onto my stomach are sections from my personal journals relating to the source of my trauma and how those around me dealt with the knowledge of the event. All of the emotions that flooded from me at the peak of my depression—the self consciousness, pain, sadness, anger, loss of hope, numbness, inability to connect—seemed to centralize in the pit of my stomach. When any of these emotions began to consume me, I would cradle my stomach, with the hope that this form of nurturing would somehow exorcise the demons from my core. 

As I collected the transcribed correspondence between my family members and me from my journal entries, I started to recognize that the words of my family members held so much weight. Even now, after seven years, I refer back to those words and adjust my behavior according to what was engrained into my psyche—“pull yourself together, it’s time to stop feeling sorry for yourself, don’t tell them.”  The words tell the story of my family members’ frustration. The lack of control the situation produced colonized my body and mind and metastasized to the bodies and minds of those around me. Very early on, my family members and I had the expectation that my pain and suffering would disappear with time. As I have come to realize that it will never truly go away, I have found ways to make living with trauma much more manageable. And through the experience of finding manageability, my family and I have discovered acceptance and a newfound understanding of one another. 

The trauma my family and I have endured, as the result of my dealings with post-traumatic stress disorder is evidence of the damaging effects communicative repression has on not only the individual but also the entire family unit. Their words are the affirmation of their suffering in reaction to my own. I am unmasking the wounds we have inflicted upon one another for the past seven years in an attempt to raise awareness of the need for divulgence when dealing with trauma.
details.name: Sticks and Stones

details.description: Back Door @ the Pendleton relocates meaning from the art object to its context by dislodging the environment while playing along its borders. Vibrant neon constructs a counterpoint by composing an air of illicitness that confronts the New England propriety of Providence’s East Side. Seeing an 18th century credenza or portrait of George Washington under a neon glow creates uncanny and conflicting visuals, relocating the meaning of the decorative art object and using humor to critique the institution. The signs lay a narrative over the surrounding objects and, I hope, heighten the viewer’s awareness of how they look at art objects and experience museums in the future.
details.name: Back Door @ the Pendleton, 2014

modules.text:
Back Door @ the Pendleton, 2014
 
Back Door @ the Pendleton relocates meaning from the art object to its context by dislodging the environment while playing along its borders. Vibrant neon constructs a counterpoint by composing an air of illicitness that confronts the New England propriety of Providence’s East Side. Seeing an 18th century credenza or portrait of George Washington under a neon glow creates uncanny and conflicting visuals, relocating the meaning of the decorative art object and using humor to critique the institution. The signs lay a narrative over the surrounding objects and, I hope, heighten the viewer’s awareness of how they look at art objects and experience museums in the future.
modules.text_plain: Back Door @ the Pendleton, 2014 Back Door @ the Pendleton relocates meaning from the art object to its context by dislodging the environment while playing along its borders. Vibrant neon constructs a counterpoint by composing an air of illicitness that confronts the New England propriety of Providence’s East Side. Seeing an 18th century credenza or portrait of George Washington under a neon glow creates uncanny and conflicting visuals, relocating the meaning of the decorative art object and using humor to critique the institution. The signs lay a narrative over the surrounding objects and, I hope, heighten the viewer’s awareness of how they look at art objects and experience museums in the future.

details.description: To convert an abandoned synagogue into a community center with a focus on food justice.
details.name: Fast Food Temple

modules.text: In this project, I had to convert an abandoned synagogue in South Providence into a gathering center for the community. The focus of the community center was to be based around food justice issues.
modules.text_plain: In this project, I had to convert an abandoned synagogue in South Providence into a gathering center for the community. The focus of the community center was to be based around food justice issues.

modules.text: In an exercise to understand the structure, I created a storyboard pairing that strived to get at the essence of the building.  I found through multiple site visits that the building was all about these barriers/thresholds that one had to step up to in order to reach the main prayer room.  In addition the site had a great sense of memory for what the synagogue once meant to the community.
modules.text_plain: In an exercise to understand the structure, I created a storyboard pairing that strived to get at the essence of the building.  I found through multiple site visits that the building was all about these barriers/thresholds that one had to step up to in order to reach the main prayer room.  In addition the site had a great sense of memory for what the synagogue once meant to the community.

modules.text: Through research I found that the neighborhood is primarily composed of immigrants from a variety of countries.  It is also a poorer community with an average household income of less that $30k.
modules.text_plain: Through research I found that the neighborhood is primarily composed of immigrants from a variety of countries.  It is also a poorer community with an average household income of less that $30k.

modules.text: Based on my research, I concluded that the people in the community didn't have the time or funds for slow food.  It makes sense why fast food is so prevalent within poorer neighborhoods (whole families can be fed with less than $5 and in under 5 minutes).  I studied the history of fast food and its development within society.
modules.text_plain: Based on my research, I concluded that the people in the community didn't have the time or funds for slow food.  It makes sense why fast food is so prevalent within poorer neighborhoods (whole families can be fed with less than $5 and in under 5 minutes).  I studied the history of fast food and its development within society.

modules.text:
Fast food, however, doesn't really provide nutrition and has led to a variety of heath problems.  
For my project, I proposed created a "fast" food temple for the community.  It would maintain the qualities that make fast food appealing BUT it would be better food that would feed the community and the community's economy.
modules.text_plain: Fast food, however, doesn't really provide nutrition and has led to a variety of heath problems.  For my project, I proposed created a "fast" food temple for the community.  It would maintain the qualities that make fast food appealing BUT it would be better food that would feed the community and the community's economy.

details.description: Many science fiction series are based on the possibility of folding or collapsing space: warp speed, hyperspace, foldspace, tesseracting. This sculpture is an optical exercise of stereoscopic vision. It exists simultaneously in sculptural space and optic space.
details.name: Sculpture (Tubes)

modules.text: Photography with a Single Lens Reflex camera falls short of the immersive experience our stereoscopic viion offers this sculpture. Space collapses and expands with a slight shift of perspective.
modules.text_plain: Photography with a Single Lens Reflex camera falls short of the immersive experience our stereoscopic viion offers this sculpture. Space collapses and expands with a slight shift of perspective.

details.description: The matriarch of my maternal family, Asmath Majarali Khan, my grandmother, has always been a source of wonder and mystique to me. Where I have spent much of my life in seclusion from family members; my maternal grandmother has spent her entire life immersed in the familial. Members of her family continually surround her, and her home is a place of refuge, a space of communion. As Grandma or Ma, as she is known in Trinidad, ages and becomes more introverted, the Khan family surrounds her more often. A continual whirlwind of activity encircles her, while she becomes less and less active. Ma: Asmath Majarali Khan is intended to be a personal investigation of time and place. The film is my process of entering and connecting to Ma’s world in order to solidify my lineage.
details.name: Ma

details.description: Using a small box, create a space that depicts a given mood/feeling.
details.name: Mood in a Box

modules.text:
Can space capture the essence of a feeling? We utilize adjective like somber, delicate, rational, etc to describe the character of spaces on a day to day basis. It is an intuitive process we engage with.
 
The challenge for this project was to begin with the mood and create a space from there. Given basic achromatic materials and predetermined dimensions to work with I was assigned three adjectives: happy, disorienting, and otherworldly. I chose to work with happy and otherworldly and then utilized light, form and texture to imbue the space with those traits.
modules.text_plain: Can space capture the essence of a feeling? We utilize adjective like somber, delicate, rational, etc to describe the character of spaces on a day to day basis. It is an intuitive process we engage with. The challenge for this project was to begin with the mood and create a space from there. Given basic achromatic materials and predetermined dimensions to work with I was assigned three adjectives: happy, disorienting, and otherworldly. I chose to work with happy and otherworldly and then utilized light, form and texture to imbue the space with those traits.

details.description: The ambient lights began as an inquiry into what already exists. Reflective surfaces used the environment provided and worked as a public lens to reflect back and the audience. The panels serve as a large mechanism to get confused your current location – to demand attention for everything that is already present. The ambient likes are neither sculpture nor furniture; they are an amalgam used to engaging passively with the environment they are viewed in.
details.name: Ambient Lights

details.description:
As everyone knows, color and geometric shapes is a universal language
that is recognizable by people from almost every different culture in the
world. But different cultures have different understanding about the
meaning of what colors and shapes carry. For example, red could represent radical, passionate, but in some culture it comes with meaning of blood and evil. I was thinking why I don’t create a new language based
on my personal subjective consciousness since I can’t find a universal
explanation from the existing knowledge. Audience will need to understand the meaning that I gave to each color, shape and position before viewing my works, and then use them as the key to decode them.

By giving every single shape, color, and position a specific meaning, I used only abstract shape, color and photo to create abstract diaries.
details.name: Abstract Diary
